Award.AwardTitle: Mass, Geometric Inequalities, and Partial Differential Equations in General Relativity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to study several important related conjectures in general relativity. This geometric theory of gravity is fundamental to our understanding of the large-scale structure of the universe, and has many practical applications such as to the fine tuning of global positioning system (GPS) technology. The PI will seek to establish families of geometric inequalities relating mass, charge, angular momentum, and horizon area, which probe the grand weak cosmic censorship conjecture. This conjecture asserts that whenever singularities arise in spacetime (which is a generic phenomenon) they must always be shrouded inside a black hole event horizon; this is intimately tied to whether general relativity is a proper deterministic theory. Special black hole solutions with symmetry (referred to as stationary axisymmetric and electro-vacuum) play a large role in our understanding of the theory, and this project seeks to classify them in higher dimensions relevant to string theory. In particular, the PI aims to prove existence and uniqueness for such black holes with exotic (lens space) topologies in five spacetime dimensions. Furthermore, new criteria for gravitational collapse and black hole formation will be studied, namely those due to concentration of angular momentum and/or charge. The PI will also examine proposed definitions of quasi-local mass in order to determine whether they are mathematically and physically viable.

Based on earlier work with Bray, the PI has recently completed a systematic approach to treating the full family of Penrose-type inequalities by reducing each to a canonical system of elliptic partial differential equations (PDEs). Thus, the entire range of these geometric inequalities is within reach. A natural by-product, associated with the study of a certain subclass of these inequalities, concerns a general procedure for constructing singular harmonic maps having 2-dimensional hyperbolic space target, which naturally arise from the stationary axisymmetric vacuum Einstein equations in four dimensions. Together with G. Weinstein, who initiated the study of such harmonic maps with prescribed singularities, we have begun development of the tools necessary to substantially generalize the 4-dimensional results to allow for exotic topologies in higher dimensions as well as a wide range of symmetric space targets.Â  Moreover, in joint work with M. Anderson, the PI has established what may be considered as the first step of Bartnik's minimal mass extension conjecture, and our methods indicate what should be a successful approach to the remaining parts. The trapped surface/hoop conjecture, dealing with the conditions under which black holes may form, is highly sought after but not well understood. However, the PI's work on Penrose-type inequalities suggests new black hole formation criteria as well as certain isoperimetric-type inequalities for relativistic bodies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary outcomes of this proposal are restuls that have improved our understanding of the concept of mass in general relativity. The techniques that we have developed and employed arise within the mathematical disciplines of geometric analysis and partial differential equations.

In collaboration with Bray, Kazaras, and Stern we have found a new and simple proof of the positive mass theorem, a result which has played a seminal role in mathematical relativity since its initial proof by Schoen, Yau, and Witten 40 years ago. This new approach, which we have also generalized to the spacetime and hyperbolic settings, yields an explicit lower bound for the mass in terms of quantities associated with (spacetime) harmonic functions, and suggests a strategy to establish the conjectured stability or almost rigidity for this theorem. 

We have established several lower bounds for the total mass in terms of the area of horizons that spacetime contains, as well as in terms of charge and angular momentum. These geometric inequalities, or Penrose inequalities, act as necessary conditions for the grand (weak) cosmic censorship and final state conjectures. The first details the nature of singularities that develop during the evolution of spacetime, in particular asserting that they should be shrouded behind an event horizon, and the second predicts that an isolated system must always settle down to a single type of black hole solution known as the Kerr(-Newman) spacetime.

Together with Weinstein and Yamada we have studied the existence, uniqueness, and classification for stationary black holes (particularly in higher dimensions with exotic topologies) and the corresponding problems for singular harmonic maps. We have developed the tools necessary to substantially generalize the classical 4D results to allow for exotic topologies in higher dimensions as well as a wide range of symmetric space targets. For instance, we have produced all possible stationary bi-axisymmetric vacuum solutions in 5-dimensions, and have begun a systematic analysis of the possible conical singularities that occur along the axes.  

In joint work with Alaee and Yau we have established Bekenstein bounds based on the Wang-Yau quasi-local mass. These inequalities concern the entropy/information contained within a relativistic body and have wide ranging implications from thermodynamics to computer science. Related to these results, the principal investigator has proven black hole existence theorems due to concentration of matter. Finding a precise mathematical formulation for this well-motivated physical statement has been an enigma since the founding of general relativity. This is a special case of the so called trapped surface or hoop conjecture which aims to determine the conditions under which gravitational collapse occurs. 

This grant has, in addition, had a significant impact in the educational arena. During the time period of this grant, the principal investigator has graduated 4 Ph.D. students and mentored a total of 7, all of which have worked on and contributed to the problems described in the initial proposal. In addition to undergraduate honors theses, the principal investigator mentored two high school students who studied black hole formation within the context of this grant. One of these students, Brian Huang, won the Siemens Competition (2017) placing 4th nationally for his project. Lastly, the principal investigator has organized several workshops, conferences, and seminars related to the topics of this grant.
